themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The inscription follows the standard formula for an Athenian decree, including the resolution by the People and the Council.

themes.label: Laws and Regulations
themes.rationale: The text explicitly mentions ancient laws and the regulation of the allotment of offices, which are central to the legal framework of the city.

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: Public decrees in the Athenian Agora were traditionally inscribed on stone stelae for public display, though the word itself is reconstructed or implied.

themes.label: Marble
themes.rationale: The standard material for monumental public inscriptions in Athens during this period was marble.

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The inscription is heavily damaged with significant portions of the text missing and reconstructed.

persons.name: Demeas son of Demas of Azenia

rationale: This inscription is an Athenian decree or law dating to the mid-1st century BC, likely following the Sullan sack of Athens. It concerns the restoration of traditional democratic practices, specifically the allotment of offices (archai) by lot and election according to 'ancient laws.' The text highlights the role of the Council of the Areopagus and the Assembly of the People in maintaining the constitutional order during a period of political transition and restoration.
